conversation.text: The first thing you need to do is to preheat the oven to 425 degrees Fahrenheit, or 220 degrees Celsius.
evidence: Preheat the oven to 425 degrees Fahrenheit (220 degrees Celsius).

conversation.text: Ok, the oven is preheating, what do I do next?
Next you have to prepare a baking dish using an "elevated cooking rack". So the meat doesn't touch the bottom.
evidence: prepare a baking dish by inserting an elevated cooking rack.

conversation.text: I don't have a cooking rack! Is there something I can use instead?
Yes, you can use crumpled up aluminum foil. Make several crumpled sheets and line the bottom of the baking dish with them.
evidence: If you don't have an elevated rack, crumple up several sheets of aluminum foil and scatter them across the bottom of the baking dish.

conversation.text: Great, sounds good. I can do that now. How do I start preparing the meat?
Next you have to "score" the meat.
evidence: Score the meat.

conversation.text: I've never scored meat before! What does that mean?
Scoring is when you use a knife and cut into the top layer of pork skin in a kind of cross-hatching pattern.
evidence: Using a sharp knife, the skin of the pork belly in a cross-hatch pattern.

conversation.text: Hmm ok. How deep do I have to cut? Does it go all the way across?
To do it properly, you should be spacing the rows out evenly. But don't cut too deep into the meat.
evidence: Slice across the skin in vertical rows spaced 2 inches (5 cm) apart, then create a series of perpendicular slices that are also spaced 2 inches (5 cm) apart.

conversation.text: But why do we need to score the meat?
Scoring the meat allows more of the fat to render out during the roasting process.
evidence: Scoring the meat in this manner will allow more of the fat to render out during the roasting process.

conversation.text: But don't we want the fat? The fat is the best part! I thought we'd want to keep as much of it as possible?
It's what gives the meat a crispy top!
evidence: Scoring the meat in this manner will allow more of the fat to render out during the roasting process.

conversation.text: That makes sense! The meat is feeling very firm, and the scores are nice and even. What next?
conversation.chosenReferece: Hey, thanks for pointing that out. It's very helpful! Here'll be my next question: What is the best way to let the meat s

conversation.text: Now we have to season the meat with oil, salt and pepper. You need to run the oil into the skin, then sprinkle on the salt and pepper.
evidence: Rub in the oil, salt, and pepper.
Place the pork belly on your prepared baking rack with the skin-side facing up.
Rub the top with oil, then generously season the meat with salt and pepper.

conversation.text: Ok. How much salt and pepper should I be using?
You want to be using a generous amount! And work it into all the slits in the skin.
evidence: generously season the meat with salt and pepper.

conversation.text: Does this help make the skin tasty?
Yes! And so does the oil. Are you finished with the seasoning?
evidence: the oil and salt make it easier for the fat to render out, resulting in crispier skin.

conversation.text: Yes! Do I need to use any other spices?
Not yet. If you do that too early the spices will burn. How does the meat look?
evidence: Note that salt and pepper should withstand the roasting process without deteriorating, but other spices and herbs might burn.

conversation.text: The meat is looking a little oily, but all the salt and pepper is on there. Do we put it in the oven next?
Yes, now we can put it in the oven for 20-30 minutes. But first, has your oven finished preheating?
evidence: Cook for 20 to 30 minutes.

conversation.text: I think so! It beeps when it's preheated, and it just started beeping. I'm putting it in now! How will I know when it's done?
The skin should look brown and crispy. How does it look now?
evidence: Roast it for 20 to 30 minutes, or until the skin browns and begins to look crispy.

conversation.text: Still pretty pink! But 20 minutes doesn't seem like enough time to cook the meat through. Won't it be raw?
It won't be cooked all the way. This is just to crisp the skin. Is any crisping happening? Or is it still looking pretty white and raw?
evidence: This brief period of high heat will not cook the pork through, nor should you cook the pork belly at this high heat for the entire time.

conversation.text: Oh! Yes, little bubbles of brown skin are forming! It looks like the skin is getting cooked and crispy!
That's great! What does it smell like?
evidence: until the skin browns and begins to look crispy.

conversation.text: It's smells pretty meaty and fatty. Is that normal?
I think so. Is it looking too brown? Or is it a golden colour?
evidence: Do not wait for the skin to become dark brown or fully crisped since it will continue cooking at a lower temperature.

conversation.text: I think it's a dark golden! Does that mean I have to take it out?
I think dark golden is probably ok. Does it smell burnt at all? Is it smoking?
evidence: Cooking it for too much time at a high heat could cause it to burn before the rest of the meat finishes.

conversation.text: No, there's no smoke! It's not dark either. What do I do now?
Now you want to turn down the heat! Turn it down to 350 degrees, and leave it for 2 hours.
evidence: Decrease the heat to 350 degrees Fahrenheit

conversation.text: TWO HOURS?! But I want the pork belly for dinner, and it's already 5pm!
Well, yeah. It has to cook for a long time. Do you have anything to snack on in the meantime?
evidence: cook for another 2 to 2-1/2 hours, or until done

conversation.text: I've got some Ritz Bits I guess. I just wasn't expecting it to take so long.
Just don't leave the room! Are you keeping an eye on it? Apparently it can start to smoke if it gets too hot.
evidence: If the fat gets too hot, it may start to smoke, and you'll need to transfer the meat to a clean baking dish.

conversation.text: Really? What temperature does it need to get to?
Do you have a thermometer you can use to check on it?
evidence: pork belly must reach a minimum internal temperature of 160 degrees

conversation.text: I have a meat thermometer!
Oh good! Are you able to check on it? What temperature is it at?
evidence: pork belly must reach a minimum internal temperature of 160 degrees Fahrenheit

conversation.text: It's not quite there yet. Even though it's looking brown and done.
Ok, if it's not there yet, you can't take it out. How is it smelling?
evidence: The pork belly must reach a minimum internal temperature of 160 degrees Fahrenheit (70 degrees Celsius) before you remove it from the oven.

conversation.text: Ok, if it's not there yet, you can't take it out. How is it smelling?

procedure.summary: Preheat the oven to 425 degrees Fahrenheit (220 degrees Celsius).
procedure.description: Meanwhile, prepare a baking dish by inserting an elevated cooking rack. If you don't have an elevated rack, crumple up several sheets of aluminum foil and scatter them across the bottom of the baking dish. You'll need to keep the pork belly elevated as it cooks to help the fat render more readily.

Using a sharp knife, the skin of the pork belly in a cross-hatch pattern. Slice across the skin in vertical rows spaced 2 inches (5 cm) apart, then create a series of perpendicular slices that are also spaced 2 inches (5 cm) apart. Pierce through the tough skin and the top layer of fat, but do not cut too deeply into the actual meat lying beneath the two. Scoring the meat in this manner will allow more of the fat to render out during the roasting process.

procedure.summary: Rub in the oil, salt, and pepper.
procedure.description: Place the pork belly on your prepared baking rack with the skin-side facing up. Rub the top with oil, then generously season the meat with salt and pepper. In addition to seasoning the meat, the oil and salt make it easier for the fat to render out, resulting in crispier skin. Apply the seasonings by hand, and work the salt and pepper into the slits across the skin. Note that salt and pepper should withstand the roasting process without deteriorating, but other spices and herbs might burn. If you decide to add others, do so within the final 30 minutes of cooking.

Place the seasoned pork belly in the preheated oven. Roast it for 20 to 30 minutes, or until the skin browns and begins to look crispy. This brief period of high heat will not cook the pork through, nor should you cook the pork belly at this high heat for the entire time. The intense heat is only meant to crisp the skin. Do not wait for the skin to become dark brown or fully crisped since it will continue cooking at a lower temperature. Cooking it for too much time at a high heat could cause it to burn before the rest of the meat finishes.

procedure.summary: Decrease the heat to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (180 degrees Celsius).
procedure.description: Decrease the temperature without removing the pork belly. Allow the meat to cook for another 2 to 2-1/2 hours, or until done. Check the pork belly halfway through the cooking process. If the fat gets too hot, it may start to smoke, and you'll need to transfer the meat to a clean baking dish. The pork belly must reach a minimum internal temperature of 160 degrees Fahrenheit (70 degrees Celsius) before you remove it from the oven.

procedure.summary: Let it rest for 10 to 15 minutes.
procedure.description: After removing the pork belly from the oven, allow it to rest for 10 to 15 minutes before carving it. During this time, the juices should distribute themselves and settle within the meat.

Roasted pork belly will have crispy skin, but the inner meat should be tender and moist. Store any leftovers in an airtight container in your refrigerator. When reheating the leftovers, sear the slices in a skillet so that the skin remains crispy.
